div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin November 13th ‘15
div1.p: Well, I have some news about my shift to Avord. My friend Thierry - Delanone has fallen ill with dipheria [diphtheria], and the Change of Ministry has ousted the gentleman we were counting on. Tant pis. [sic] Oh well, I now have a new line open direct to the ear of that distinguished and famous man of arms, ycleft [sp?] General Galleinie, or how ever you spell him, and so I’m waiting for results there. Failing in the Avord wish I’ll go to Pau. I may go to Paris and wait around putting in a personal appeal now and then, which ought to speed things up.

Thanks for your complimentary remarks avent the Article in “Outlook”[.] Glad it pleased you. Some high official read it someplace and sat up and asked himself about the blooming section. It got action, and no less an individual that the right honorable Gaudet (over)
came breezing out and got off the usual “bunk” about Liberty, Civilization and Lafayette. They’re smearing it on these days.

I’ve no more news save to announce the arrival of a fellow named Pottle who is a wonder. A writes who hails from the Lake Como gang. One of the best fellows I ever met. That, and the fact that I have at last queered myself permanently with my family constitutes the news to date. For one thing they won’t stand for my attitude toward the States and for another because I won’t go home and help out during the hard times prevailing. The last attempt to get me back consisted in an offer from my brother in law of a job that would pay me five thousand a year if I made good. I turned it down and told them to accept things as they were or
to stop writing. I know I’m wrong, and mean, and a slob, and everything else, but I happen to be constituted that way and I just as well be frank about it.

When do you plan that vacation of yours? I’m hoping Ned will be back around the 1st of December and if so I shall shortly after that pack up my tooth brush and hie [sic] me to La Belle Paris en route to Avord or Pau. Hope I land while your vacation is still on. We can have a couple afternoons floating around someplace if you are willing to honor me with the pleasure of your extremely pleasant company.
Do let me know how you are getting on, Mlle. Marcelle Guerin of Paris, New York and the A.A. Paul’s wedding is put off until end of the war. Don’t give him a suspicion of what I’ve said will you?
